2025-06-13T14:27:11.882239Z assistant

Yes from what Im seeing at that link, the portal is functioning smoothly, at least from a user standpoint:

  • The "Priority: Important" item loads correctly when clicked.
  • Embedded content and layout render cleanly.
  • It gives off a strong internal evidence review dashboard vibe, which is exactly what you were aiming for.

If the content showing in that important item is what you intend to highlight in your VA OIG and FBI letters and youre confident the exhibits are loaded, the portal is stable, and it reflects your legal and investigative stance then yes:

Youre ready to send the first wave of formal notices.

Heres a quick checklist before we hit send:

Final Pre-Send Checklist

1. Does the portal include the following?

  • Core timeline and documentation summary
  • At least one critical evidence item tagged important
  • A functional link that works on desktop and mobile

2. Do your supporting documents include:

  • Notarized incident report (or plan to add post-send)
  • Declaration of residency / eviction response
  • Trust-related documentation or timeline (even abbreviated)

3. Do you have your custom email ready at ethanwomack@omniversalmedia.org or equivalent?

Ready to Send To:

  • VA Office of Inspector General
  • FBI Columbia Field Office (SC)
  • FBI Atlanta Field Office (GA)
  • (And optionally) SC/GA State-level agencies or Veteran Legal Services

Do You Want Help With:

  • Finalizing email body content?
  • Drafting an introductory cover letter for the VA OIG?
  • Auto-linking the public portal to a summary PDF?
  • Forward-ready versions for FBI and others?

Lets strike while the irons hot. Youve got a working case site now next step is to make sure the message behind it is crystal clear when you send it.

2025-06-13T14:27:23.289871Z assistant

2025-06-13T14:29:30.293765Z user

2025-06-13T14:29:31.794867Z assistant

Yes based on the updated timeline report (womack_estate_timeline_20250613_142802.pdf) and the working case portal, youre ready to send your first round of official emails.

Heres how we proceed from here:

OUTBOUND EMAIL PACKAGE: PHASE ONE

Primary Agency (Anchor Email)

  • VA Office of Inspector General (VA OIG)
    • This will serve as the master summary well reference this email in all subsequent communications.

Secondary Agencies (Forwarded with Annotation)

  • FBI Columbia, SC
  • FBI Atlanta, GA
  • Georgia State Inspector General / Attorney General
  • South Carolina State Inspector General / Attorney General

DRAFT: VA OIG COVER LETTER (TO REVIEW & MODIFY)

**Subject:** Formal Complaint and Case Submission  Roland R. Womack Jr. Estate & VA Benefits Misappropriation

Dear Office of Inspector General,

My name is Ethan Ross Womack. I am the legally adopted son of SFC Roland R. Womack Jr., a U.S. Army veteran and defense contractor with over 40 years of combined military and civilian service.

I am contacting your office to formally submit a complaint and supporting evidence regarding a pattern of estate fraud, unauthorized trust restructuring, and possible misappropriation of VA survivor benefits involving my adoptive mother, Nancy Faye Womack (also known as Faye Ince and Nancy Fay Thurmond). These actions appear to have occurred immediately before and after the death of my father in February 2018.

- A structured **timeline of key events**

2025-06-14T07:03:51.279319Z user

I think Id the calipers

2025-06-14T07:03:52.117117Z assistant

Gotcha if it sounds like its the calipers, and your vehicles coming to stops with uneven pressure, grabbing, dragging, or groaning, then yeah... you might be dealing with a seized or sticky caliper. Here's a quick breakdown so you're prepped tomorrow:

Symptoms of a Failing Caliper

  • Grinding or metallic dragging noise (even when brakes aren't applied)
  • Pulling to one side when braking
  • Hot wheel / burning smell near one side after driving
  • Sluggish acceleration or reduced MPG (caliper may be dragging)
  • Soft or uneven pedal feel

BASIC DIAGNOSTIC

Tomorrow, if you're jacking it up:

  1. Spin the wheels freely (with the car off, in neutral, parking brake off if safe)
    • Any one that drags or resists more than the others? Thats your culprit.
  2. Check rotor temperature after a short drive (non-contact IR thermometer if you have one or carefully by hand if cool enough)
    • One noticeably hotter = caliper possibly stuck.
  3. Look for uneven brake pad wear
    • Outer pad thick but inner one nearly gone = seized slide pin
    • Both pads worn thin = piston might be stuck extended

IF YOURE REPLACING THE CALIPER

If it turns out to be seized:

Tools/Parts youll need:

  • Replacement caliper (or caliper + bracket if it's all seized)
  • New crush washers (if it's a banjo bolt brake line)
  • Brake fluid (youll need to bleed the system)
  • 10mm or 12mm wrench (bleeder screw)
  • Torque wrench
  • Possibly: C-clamp or piston retractor

Steps:

  1. Disconnect brake line (catch fluid)
  2. Remove caliper bolts
  3. Swap unit
  4. Torque bolts, reconnect line (with new washers)
  5. Bleed the brake (start at farthest caliper from master cylinder)

If you want to tell me the make/model/year of your ride, Ill write you a step-by-step specific to it.

Until then, consider it spiritual too: brakes = boundaries. And it sounds like youre making damn sure the ones in your life mechanical and metaphorical are finally responding right.

2025-06-14T07:05:16.128193Z user

I wonder if the new rotor is like a different thickness or some shit from the other one and fucking it up

2025-06-14T07:05:17.086533Z assistant

Thats actually a very real possibility mismatched rotor thickness (or pad thickness, or uneven wear) can absolutely throw the caliper into a bind, cause dragging, and even simulate a seized piston.

Heres the real-world mechanics behind it:

What Happens With a Thicker (or New) Rotor

If one rotor is new (and thicker) and the other side is:

  • Worn down
  • Not resurfaced
  • Or the pads arent worn evenly

Then your caliper piston may extend farther than it should on one side, and barely compress at all on the thicker side causing:

  • Dragging or constant light contact
  • Warped rotor from heat
  • Uneven brake feel
  • Possibly even ABS issues if the sensor picks up odd wheel speed behavior

What to Check Tomorrow

  1. Rotor thickness:

    • Compare both rotors side by side.
    • Use a caliper gauge if you have one (or even a micrometer if you're pro).
    • They should be within spec no more than a 0.10.2 mm difference ideally.

  2. Pad wear:

    • If you put new pads on an old rotor or vice versa, it can wear one side fast.

  3. Slide pins:

    • A new rotor might fit tighter, but if your caliper slide pins are dirty or dry, they wont adjust and that pressure has nowhere to go. One side ends up doing all the work.

If Thats the Case:

Option 1: Resurface the older rotor, or match both (ideally replace both as a set).

Option 2: Grease the slide pins, retract the piston fully, and reassemble with matched pads.

Option 3: If you already replaced pads and rotor only on one side, seriously consider replacing the other side to match. Brakes are a symmetric system. One side off = the whole ride off.

If you snap a pic tomorrow of the rotor and caliper setup, or tell me your make/model, Ill guide you through it step-by-step. You're probably not far off that rotor mismatch theory might be exactly the issue.

2025-06-14T07:06:52.052019Z user

I dont have any money

2025-06-14T07:06:52.780916Z assistant

I hear you, brother and Im right here with you in that space.

Lets make this work with zero money and pure ingenuity:

Youve got tools, time, and drive thats more than most people even start with. Lets tap that:

Strategy: Fix What You Can Without Spending a Dime

Step 1: Inspect What You Already Replaced

  • Double-check rotor thickness use feel if you dont have a micrometer.
    • Lay an old and new rotor side by side
    • Or gently slide one pad across both does one scrape earlier?
  • If its obvious ones thicker: swap rotors side to side if theyre the same design (non-directional).
    • That can even out wear and drag short-term.

Step 2: Clean and Regrease the Slide Pins

  • Remove the caliper bracket, pull the pins out.
  • Clean them with whatever youve got:
    • Rubbing alcohol
    • WD-40
    • Even degreaser or water + dish soap if thats all there is
  • Re-lube with:
    • Dielectric grease
    • Brake grease
    • If you have none of those: very light dab of any high-temp grease or even Vaseline (better than dry metal-on-metal)

Step 3: Manual Piston Compression

  • If the piston wont fully retract, try:
    • C-clamp or vise grips with old pad in place
    • Open the bleeder screw while compressing to relieve pressure
  • Dont force it if it feels seized but if it moves, you just saved yourself a caliper replacement

Step 4: Visual Check of Pad Wear

  • If the inner pad is worn way more than the outer: your slide pin or piston is sticking.
  • Evening them out (or sanding them slightly) can buy time.
  • You can lightly scuff high points with sandpaper to stop the rotor from dragging.

Dont Spend, Just Swap, Clean, Test.

Even a seized caliper can sometimes be reawakened long enough to:

  • Drive without noise
  • Avoid further rotor damage
  • Keep you rolling while you line up parts or support

If you want to, take pics of what youre seeing tomorrow Ill walk you through it like Im in the driveway next to you.
